Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: The grandfather notices his grandchild seems to be feeling lost or discouraged about a personal matter.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story:
I sat on the park bench, watching my grandson kick at the gravel with a heavy sigh. His shoulders slumped, and I could sense the weight he carried, the kind that only comes from feeling lost. My instinct as a grandfather was to reach out, to share a story from my own youth, to offer the kind of guidance I wished someone had given me. I wanted to tell him that it’s okay to feel uncertain, that life has a way of working itself out, but I hesitated, not wanting to push him before he was ready.

Just then, my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old acquaintance from the neighborhood. “Hey, do you know any good places to eat around here?” he texted. Mark rarely reached out, and I knew he wouldn’t ask unless he really needed a suggestion. I felt torn—my grandson needed my attention, my presence, and my wisdom, but Mark was expecting a quick, helpful reply. I stared at my phone, feeling the pull of both roles, unsure which expectation to meet first.
